support.p: Monument Dyfed Archaeological Trust Historic Environment Record: 2473 St Mary's Church
support.note: Comprised of porphyritic andesite. Subhedral phenocrysts of feldspar and pyroxene (Edwards 2007, 498).

layoutDesc.layout: No ogam is presently visible on the stone but there is a roman-letter, Latin inscription consisting of three lines reading vertically downwards (Edwards 2007, 498).

handDesc.handNote: There is no evidence to indicate how the ogham inscription might have been carved, so the execution technique remains unknown. The Latin inscription is medium-incised using fine lines (Edwards 2007, 498). The inscription is in capitals... In line 1 VA are ligatured; the horizontal of the L slopes downwards, the first stroke of the N is slightly extended and the terminating I is horizontal. In line 2 VN are ligatured. In line 3 the outer strokes of the M are widely spaced and the inner strokes touch the line; MA are conjoined; R has a shortened diagonal and S in elongated (Edwards 2007, 498).

div.p: of Evalus son of Denovus, of Cuniovenda his mother

It is unclear whether Cuniovenda was the mother of Evalus or his father, though the former is more likely. The use of the word mater is unique amongst the early inscribed stones... (Edwards 2007, 498). It is likely that EVALI is intended as the genitive of the rare Latin name Aevalis or a derivative *Aevalius... The patronymic, however, is presumably Celtic, whether it is read DENOVI or DENCVI. If DENOVI is read, it may be a Welsh adaption (with British O for the Irish composition vowel A) - or a cognate - of the Irish name *Dena-vi(ks), "swift fighter"... If the reading is DENCVI it may be a Welsh name in -wy (or Latin -uus) to the Celtic base *denk- that is seen in Ir. Déclán... The first element of the latter name [CVNIOVENDE] should be compared with CIIC, nos 289 CUNIA and 286 CUNEA in Ireland... rather than with the commonplace element Cuno-, "hound", from which it presumably derives (Macalister 1945, 281-284). The composition vowel is British rather than Irish. The second element is Celtic *-wind-, "white" (plus Latin gen. sg. ending) (Edwards 2007, 498-500).
